3.69.text:
I think one of the
key things for me

5.66.text:
is you this question--
what is R&D?

9.17.text:
I think it's at
least as varied--

12.03.text:
in practise and
in the question--

16.08.text:
So if we've been doing anything
at watershed over the last 15

21.01.text:
years, it's going on a
journey with all of the people

23.57.text: that we work with and for.

26.01.text:
As Ruth said, it's
been a journey that's

27.68.text:
about artist and audience,
it's about collision.

31.67.text:
Sometimes it ends up in car
crash, sometimes we're lucky

35.00.text: and we get a bit of fusion.

37.99.text:
But for me, it's all
about the questions.

40.66.text:
It's all about questions
that galvanise new thinking.

45.29.text:
And what digital has
done, is brilliantly

47.87.text:
disrupt-- I mean, I just
love that messy space

51.33.text:
when you really don't
know what's going on.

54.28.text:
Every now and then I've be
known to start pontificating

57.14.text:
and it sounds like I know what
I'm doing, if I do that today,

61.30.text:
The key thing is keep
stepping into the space

63.21.text:
where you don't know
what's going on.

66.14.text:
So what we've been
up to is-- if I'm

68.73.text:
going to try to use
some buzz words--

70.99.text:
we talk about innovating
at the intersection of art,

76.59.text:
And I think the
society bit is probably

78.88.text:
the most important
bit in those three.

82.34.text:
So while we built a reputation
in the early oughties

85.12.text:
is very much through publishing
lots of stuff on the web.

90.50.text:
At the time half
of our reputation

92.49.text:
was completely chimeric,
because most people

97.52.text:
Most people hadn't actually
seen what we were up to.

101.84.text:
We really built a
reputation-- this

103.50.text:
was before YouTube or
any of those things.

106.38.text:
But for us, it was never
about the finished product.

109.92.text:
It was never about the
publishing and distribution.

112.53.text: It was always about the network.

114.53.text:
Is all about how could we
build capacity in the network.

118.39.text:
How could we build a
much stronger system?

126.44.text:
I mean the Internet
is a network,

128.47.text:
it's a communication system,
the power is at the periphery.

132.61.text:
We've certainly seen
that in the Middle East.

135.15.text:
No longer is it a
broadcast world.

138.37.text:
It's absolutely about
a connected world.

140.91.text:
And so the power is
at the periphery.

143.16.text:
And so it's very much for us
about value in the network,

150.75.text:
There was one moment
where we really

154.50.text:
It was about 2005, we
did a very big project

157.10.text:
with HP, who happened to
have their European research

163.38.text:
HP reliably tell
us that we produced

166.24.text:
the first films
made in the cloud.

169.24.text:
It wasn't called the
cloud at that time,

173.45.text:
It got us into some very,
very difficult, hot water,

179.31.text:
They really didn't
think we should

180.73.text:
be helping a big corporate
develop new technology.

185.21.text:
It made you just
go, OK if we're not

187.69.text:
being understood
let's step over here.

190.85.text:
And actually was a great
moment, because it just

193.05.text:
gave us the confidence to
step into a bigger world,

197.31.text:
Not leaving the arts behind,
but cross a boundary.

202.76.text:
And it was very much
thought that sense

206.31.text:
that we could actually be
a value to a big corporate,

209.21.text:
as well as local artists and
audiences, and the arts world,

214.27.text:
that began to get
us really thinking

217.97.text:
And we've actually
come to understand

219.93.text:
that if we're completely
comfortable with our funders,

222.34.text:
we're probably
not doing our job.

224.27.text:
We're probably not

226.06.text:
We're probably not
asking our own question,

231.24.text:
So the focus is very much on
talent, on emergent practise,

234.80.text:
very much about
letting the idea lead.

237.63.text:
Don't follow the funding,

240.70.text:
to help the talent

245.40.text:
We work all the time with a
whole mix-- academics, artists,

252.00.text:
Many of them co-located in

255.59.text:
Where everyone's equal,
everyone's got knowledge,

258.72.text:
and it's the difference
that drives to the power.

261.38.text:
And the whole deal is,
if you work with us

264.30.text:
You've got to help
somebody else.

266.51.text:
And it's very much
about fail every day.

268.96.text:
And that just becomes,
hey another failure.

271.73.text:
But make sure you
learn every day

273.64.text:
and share the learning to
build a much stronger and more

278.80.text:
And critically, it's about

281.92.text:
For me, diversity is
our big untapped asset

286.54.text:
If you're not being
off awkward questions

288.98.text:
you're not going to
have to think fresh.

292.47.text:
We recently ran a state
of the arts conference.

295.42.text:
We called it 'No Boundaries',
trying to push out.

300.19.text:
Ran it with Marcus,
over there, from Pilot.

302.97.text:
We used a lot of tech, a

309.47.text:
It wasn't so much
the tech worked,

311.53.text:
it was actually the
communication setup worked.

318.74.text:
But even more than that, there
was some really good speakers.

321.29.text:
So I'm going to finish
with one from Nii Sackey,

324.01.text:
I don't know if people know Nii,
who's Chief Exec of Bigga Fish.

327.95.text:
And he said, "get comfortable
with your uncomfortableness".

333.64.text:
He was very much talking

336.85.text:
But if you don't get comfortable

339.10.text:
you're not going
